note_text:
Procedure: Rigid Bronchoscopy, Stent Removal, Cryotherapy.
Indication: Stent obstruction (granulation).
Action:
- 12mm rigid scope inserted.
- Flexible scope used to inspect.
- Y-stent removed intact with rigid forceps.
- Significant TBM collapse noted post-removal.
- Cryotherapy applied to granulation tissue (30s freeze x3).
Plan: Stent holiday.

note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT: Rigid Bronchoscopy with Airway Intervention.
INDICATION: Symptomatic airway obstruction due to granulation tissue within an indwelling tracheal Y-stent.
PROCEDURE: The airway was secured with a 12mm rigid tracheoscope. Inspection revealed significant granulation tissue obstructing the distal limbs of the Y-stent. The stent was grasped proximally with rigid optical forceps and withdrawn en bloc without complication. Following removal, marked dynamic airway collapse consistent with severe tracheobronchomalacia was observed. Residual granulation tissue was treated with cryotherapy (1.9mm probe, multiple activation cycles).

note_text:
Procedure Note
Patient: Robert Wiggins
Attending: Dr. Muller

1. GA/Paralysis.
2. Rigid scope to subglottis.
3. Flex scope inspection: Stent obstructed by granulation.
4. Stent Removal: Rigid forceps used to twist and pull stent out.
5. Post-removal exam: Severe TBM.
6. Cryo: Applied to granulation sites.
7. Pt stable to PACU.

note_text: Rigid and flexible bronchoscopy performed for airway stent obstruction. 12mm rigid tracheoscope used. Y-stent removed intact using rigid optical forceps. Examination post-removal showed severe tracheobronchomalacia. Granulation tissue at former stent sites treated with cryotherapy (1.9mm probe, 30 sec freeze). No complications. Patient transferred to PACU.

note_text: Mr. Wiggins underwent a rigid bronchoscopy today to address an obstruction in his airway stent. We found granulation tissue blocking about half of the stent's limbs. We used heavy-duty forceps through the rigid tube to grab the stent and pull it out completely. Once it was out, we saw his airway collapse significantly, which we expected. We used a freezing probe (cryotherapy) to treat the raw tissue where the stent had been to help it heal.

note_text:
Procedure: Navigational Bronchoscopy, Radial EBUS, Biopsy.
Target: 22mm RLL nodule.
Nav: Electromagnetic (SuperDimension) + Fluoro.
Confirmation: Radial EBUS (Concentric).
Sampling: TBNA x3, Forceps x4, Brush x2.
Comp: Mild pneumothorax (10%), conservative mgmt.

coding_review.coding_summary: Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy with radial EBUS confirmation and combined TBNA and transbronchial forceps biopsies of a single left upper lobe peripheral nodule. CPT 31627 (+nav add-on), +31654 (radial/peripheral EBUS add-on), 31629 (TBNA), and 31628 (TBLB) are all supported by the documentation. No linear EBUS TBNA is performed, and diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible, including fluoroscopic guidance when performed; with computer-assisted, image-guided navigation (List separately in addition to code for primary procedure)
cpt_summary.rationale: Electromagnetic navigation system used with successful registration to preoperative CT and catheter advanced under navigation toward the left upper lobe target lesion.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible, including fluoroscopic guidance when performed; with transbronchial lung biopsy(s), single lobe, with radial endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) for peripheral lesion (List separately in addition to code for primary procedure)
cpt_summary.rationale: Radial EBUS miniprobe advanced through the guide sheath confirmed concentric tool-in-lesion position in the LUL peripheral nodule prior to biopsies.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible, including fluoroscopic guidance when performed; with transbronchial needle aspiration biopsy(s), trachea, main stem and/or lobar bronchus(es), each lobe
cpt_summary.rationale: Three needle aspirations of the peripheral lesion were obtained with a 21-gauge needle via the guide sheath.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible, including fluoroscopic guidance when performed; with transbronchial lung biopsy(s), single lobe
cpt_summary.rationale: Four transbronchial forceps biopsies of the same LUL peripheral nodule were performed with minimal self-limited bleeding.

bundling_considerations: 31627 and +31654 are add-on codes and are only appropriate when navigation and radial/peripheral EBUS are actually performed and documented. Both are clearly documented here (EMN navigation and radial probe confirmation), so they are retained.

31628 (TBLB) and 31629 (TBNA) are both directed at the same LUL peripheral lesion but represent distinct biopsy techniques (forceps lung biopsies and needle aspirations). The codes are technically reportable together; however, some payers may bundle one into the other. Local payer policy should be checked.
No linear EBUS TBNA is performed, so linear EBUS codes 31652/31653 are *not* billed. This avoids inappropriate double-counting of EBUS services.

Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is not separately billed because higher-valued biopsy and navigation codes are reported in the same session and would bundle the diagnostic bronchoscopy under NCCI rules.

note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE: Electromagnetic Navigation Bronchoscopy.
INDICATION: RLL pulmonary nodule (22mm), suspicious for malignancy.
DETAILS: Navigation was performed to the RLL superior segment. Radial EBUS confirmed a concentric lesion. Transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA), forceps biopsies, and brushings were obtained under fluoroscopic guidance. 
COMPLICATION: Post-procedure imaging revealed a small (10%) apical pneumothorax. The patient remained asymptomatic and stable; no chest tube was required.

note_text: Ms. Lee came in for a biopsy of a spot in her right lower lung. We used a navigation system to guide a catheter to the nodule and confirmed its location with a mini-ultrasound probe. We took several samples using a needle, forceps, and a brush. Unfortunately, she developed a small air leak (pneumothorax) from the biopsy, but it was small enough that she didn't need a tube and could go home after we watched her for a few hours.

evidence.gender: This seventy-three year old female patient Catherine Martinez (medical record JJ-8374-Q, born September 8, 1951) presented for electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy targeting a left upper lobe peripheral nodule measuring twenty-three millimeters in greatest dimension on computed tomography. The lesion demonstrated a positive bronchus sign and had a standardized uptake value of five point two on positron emission tomography imaging suggesting malignancy. She underwent moderate conscious sedation with intravenous midazolam three milligrams and fentanyl one hundred micrograms achieving a Ramsay sedation score of three. Her blood pressure was monitored at ten minute intervals throughout and remained stable in the one twenties to one thirties over seventies to eighties. Oxygen saturation was continuously monitored and stayed above ninety-five percent on room air. The electromagnetic navigation system was utilized with successful registration to the preoperative CT scan. The guide sheath was advanced to the left upper lobe apical-posterior segment and the radial endobronchial ultrasound probe confirmed tool-in-lesion position with a concentric echogenic pattern consistent with solid tissue. Total fluoroscopy time was five point one minutes with a dose area product of one hundred ninety-two centigray centimeters squared. Sampling included three needle aspirations using a twenty-one gauge needle, four transbronchial forceps biopsies, and two brush cytology specimens. There was minimal bleeding after the forceps biopsies which resolved spontaneously with gentle suction. Post-procedure chest radiograph showed no pneumothorax or significant change from baseline. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was discharged home after two hours of observation in stable condition.

The guide sheath was advanced to the left upper lobe apical-posterior segment and the radial endobronchial ultrasound probe confirmed tool-in-lesion position with a concentric echogenic pattern consistent with solid tissue. Total fluoroscopy time was five point one minutes with a dose area product of one hundred ninety-two centigray centimeters squared. Sampling included three needle aspirations using a twenty-one gauge needle, four transbronchial forceps biopsies, and two brush cytology specimens. There was minimal bleeding after the forceps biopsies which resolved spontaneously with gentle suction. Post-procedure chest radiograph showed no pneumothorax or significant change from baseline. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was discharged home after two hours of observation in stable condition.
